title: Similar to FF Bau and Arial
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317184515im_/http:/typophile.com/files/font_5669.jpg)

What stands out is de double story 'g' and the round dots above the 'i' and the descender of the 'y' doesn't have a curve.

Here's a link to see FF Bau:  
 [http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff\_bau\_web\_medium/web\_t...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317184515/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_bau_web_medium/web_tt/specimen/samples/ "http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff\_bau\_web\_medium/web\_tt/specimen/samples/")

Thank you for helping!

Font: 

 Apercu Bold 

Solved By: 

 [kthomps5](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317184515/http:/typophile.com/user/175823 "View user profile.")
author: heemanhey

comments.content:
Not Brown or Circular, by Lineto.

I'm sure we've discussed this double-story g with the square ear before, but I can't remember its name....

Heyman, is this from a print publication, or museum signage?

The more details you can provide, the better we can narrow down the foundry.

Productus from Font Bureau has a similar g and i, but isn't right for the rest of the alphabet....  
 [http://www.fontbureau.com/fonts/sans/Productus/styles/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317184515/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/sans/Productus/styles/ "http://www.fontbureau.com/fonts/sans/Productus/styles/")

Kevin, thank you so much for your question.  
It's a publication from Unseen. This is the website:  
 [http://www.unseenamsterdam.com/tags/magazine](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317184515/http:/www.unseenamsterdam.com/tags/magazine "http://www.unseenamsterdam.com/tags/magazine")

I notice the same font is used on the website and I simply used the browsers 'inspect element' to find the font  
Apercu Bold

[http://fontdeck.com/font/apercu/bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317184515/http:/fontdeck.com/font/apercu/bold "http://fontdeck.com/font/apercu/bold")
Ow and all the others, thanks for your efforts, it's really appreciated!
How dit you found it so fast not even knowing the website, and the source of the publication?

I knew it had to be one of the new, "trendy" sans serifs, and if it wasn't Lineto's Brown or Circular, I could still find it here:

[www.fontsinuse.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317184515/http:/www.fontsinuse.com/ "www.fontsinuse.com")

Thank goodness its name started with an "a"....

haha, well thank you for your help!  
And that website is one to bookmark!  
Cheers Heyman
